newsitem.title: Australia: RTRS-Flat Australian bonds nap ahead of big week.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Flat Australian bonds nap ahead of big week.

text.p: *Australian bonds shrug off stronger tone in U.S. market to finish flat on an uninspired day's trading.
*Fall in current accopunt deficit fails to stir the market, which awaits plethora of events next week.

Australian bonds put in a lacklustre performance on Friday, shrugging off a firmer tone in Treasuries and a massive drop in the nation's current account deficit to finish flat to softer across the curve.
"It's taken a heck of a long time to do nothing much today," one trader said, adding the focus was more on events next week.

A 25 percent improvement in the December current account deficit to A$1.4 billion had little market impact, traders instead squaring up ahead of U.S. GDP data later today and also winding down ahead of the weekend.
"U.S. GDP could have a bit of an impact on our markets, particularly if it is a big number," another trader said.
Next week is a busy week both locally and abroad for bonds, with a number of events that could change market sentiment, or in the minds of the most bullish, deliver a local rate cut.
Domestically the key events are the RBA Board meeting on Tuesday, the same day as the release of December retail trade data, and fourth quarter wages data on Thursday.
Traders said the key U.S. events next week are the FOMC meeting and next Friday's employment report.

Bonds spreads end wider across the board as the local market trades flat to weaker while U.S. Treasuries continue firmer tone in Tokyo. Futures curve pulls back a notch after steepening through the week.
